All,

This is slightly off-topic, but I figure you guys are the best ones to
ask on this subject...

I am trying to envision a network model where the connectivity is
adapted over time.  What I picture is patterned after the biological
neuron, attempting to model the role of neurotransmitters in
connection growth.

First, a quick summary of the model I have in mind:  The system would
start out with neurons that are placed in space relative to one
another.  There is a 'distance' between each neuron and every other
neuron, calculated based on the spatial distance.  But there are
initially no connections.

Some neurons are connected to particular inputs, some to particular
outputs.  Then the simulation is allowed to play out, and as inputs
come in, it starts stimulating the network.

When a neuron fires, two things happen.  First, it releases
neurotransmitters to all of its connected-to neighbors, just like a
normal network.  Then, it also prompts growth of new connections
and/or strengthening of existing connections.  The strengthening is
proportional to the neurotransmitter density at each neighbor,
modified by distance to that neighbor.

This means that if there are three neurons, A, B, and C, and both A
and B fire at nearly the same time, then as A is growing dendrites, it
will be more likely to grow them in the direction of B than of C. 
Likewise B will grow them towards A.  Hence, a connection will
ultimately form between A and B.  If my understanding is correct, this
is approximately what Hebbian learning is.

Additionally, each neuron will 'accumulate' the received
neurotransmitters, moving them from the surface to the center for use
in its own firing, at a rate that is directly related to the density
of neurotransmitters on the surface.  This gives the activation
potential a 'half-life' so to speak.  This gradual fall-off allows a
time-delay aspect so that temporally related firings do in fact
influence one another without having to have complex methods of
detecting 'concurrence' for the sake of the Hebbian learning.

So, my question to the group is:  Does this sound familiar?  If so, do
you have any links or keywords I can search on to read more about work
along these lines?

-- John
